title: Podcast Pick: Hear Supreme Court show 'More Perfect' before we get a new justice
text:
Podcast Pick: Hear Supreme Court show 'More Perfect' before we get a new justice Carly Mallenbaum , USA TODAY 9:40 a.m. ET Feb. 4, 2017 
WNYC show 'More Perfect' tells stories about the Supreme Court that appeal to more than just law students. (Photo: Courtesy WNYC) 
Looking for something new to listen to while you drive to work/go for a walk/wash the dishes? We're here for you. In a weekly series, we're highlighting a podcast, audio personality or specific story worth hearing. This week's pick: Radiolab presents More Perfect 
Last June, the producers of popular Radiolab debuted their first spin-off: a show about the Supreme Court. The six episodes from Season 1 are available now, and Season 2 is coming later this year. To that, we say, "Oyez!" Why it's ripe for listening Object Anyway 
As the Trump administration prepares to confirm a new Supreme Court justice, you might be wondering, 'What have the Supremes been up to all of this time?' Well, More Perfect has some profound and fascinating answers. 
Even if you've never taken a law class or read a court case, listening to the WNYC mini-series feels like drawing a warm bath of knowledge for your brain. From stories about how a ruling meant to eliminate race-based jury selection made the problem worse (" Object Anyway "), to a case that gave one justice a nervous breakdown (" Political Thicket "), the stories about nine people in robes are stimulating, eye-opening and worth sharing. Memorable line 
In a montage of audio, people describe on Supreme Court justice in "Political Thicket:" 
"Justice Frankfurter was one of the most influential justices of all time ... as a person, Justice Frankfurter wasn't necessarily the nicest person ... I always call him a 'bantam rooster' ... he was a difficult, crusty figure ... he was short, and he had a little bit of a pouch on him ... he was one of the most ... condescending ... egotistical of justices." 
To se last week's podcast pick, go here . Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Each week, we highlight a 'Podcast Pick' worth hearing. Some of the shows on our list? 'Love + Radio,' 'Embedded' and 'More Perfect.' Courtesy Love + Radio, NPR, More Perfect Fullscreen If you're answer to "How are you?" is "Terrible, thanks for asking," then this podcast is for you. Podcast host Nora McInerny's tender and candid storytelling turns sob stories of loss into engaging tales of life and love. 'TTFA' feels like a warm, tear-stained hug. American Public Media The 'Secrets, Crimes and Audiotape' podcast presents an immersive adaptation of 'The Handmaid's Tale,' right before Hulu releases a series based on the classic novel. Courtesy Wondery If hearing about severed body parts doesn't bother you, 'Hollywood & Crime' is a worthy listen. In the show's first season, it tackles unsolved Black Dahlia murder, which took place 70 years ago. Courtesy Wondery Gimlet Media podcast 'Startup' had plenty of access to controversial former American Apparel CEO Dov Charney, which made for a candid and insightful fourth season of their show. Gary Friedman, AP 'The Hilarious World of Depression,' hosted by John Moe, presents frank (and funny) conversations with comedians who suffer from clinical depression. The insightful show aims to help people with depression feel less alone. Courtesy APM Fullscreen In 'With Special Guest Lauren Lapkus,' comedian and actress Lapkus ('Jurassic World,' 'Orange is the New Black') has her real guests play fictional podcast hosts. She plays a guest on their show, in the improvised audio show that goes in unexpected directions. Emma McIntyre On the three-part WBEZ podcast 'Making Oprah,' host Jenn White uses interviews (with, yes, Oprah and others) to tell the story of how a local TV co-host became one of the most influential people in the country. STEVE GREEN, Associated Press The creators of 'The Jinx' present 'Crimetown,' a riveting Gimlet Media show about corruption in different cities, starting with Providence, R.I. Tagline: "You can never tell the good guys from the bad guys." Courtesy Gimley Catherine Keener, David Schwimmer and Oscar Isaac voice characters in the meticulously-produced Gimlet thriller 'Homecoming,' which runs for six episodes. Courtesy Gimlet New podcast 'Broadway Backstory' tells behind-the-scenes stories of hit Broadway musicals. Host Patrick Hinds features Lin-Manuel Miranda in his first show to talk about the 'Hamilton' scribe's first hit, 'In the Heights.' Courtesy TodayTix The 'Presidential' podcast, from 'The Washington Post' editor Lillian Cunningham, has an insightful episode on every single U.S. president. Yep, even the ones you forgot about. Courtesy The Washington Post On 'Crybabies,' Sarah Thyre and Susan Orlean have their guests explains what pieces of music, movies and theater make them cry. Earwolf/E.W. Scripps Company We recommend 'Lore,' a bi-weekly horror series from thriller author Aaron Mahnke. Courtesy of Lore The podcast 'Criminal' is about "people who've done wrong, been wronged, or gotten caught somewhere in the middle." The episode that features this art is about a police dog named Talon. Courtesy Radiotopia CBC Radio's 'Love Me' podcast has touching stories about human connection. Ben Shannon, Courtesy of CBC Jonathan Goldstein, who was on 'This American Life' and the now-defunct 'Wire Tap,' has a new series, 'Heavyweight,' about road trips, thorny reunions and difficult conversations. Courtesy Heavyweight Jenna and Bodhi Elfman are the voices of Franny and Jim, a couple that has to figure out whether they're still in love in the audio drama "A Beautiful Spell" from the new show 'Secrets, Crimes and Audiotape.' Courtesy of Wondery The podcast 'FOUND' will have you caring more about the lives of strangers. It shares stories of abandoned items. Courtesy Wondery The Canadian podcast 'Grownups Read Things They Wrote as Kids' is exactly what it sounds like. And it's surprisingly compelling. Evan Mitsui Is organic food really better for you? Does the so-called G-spot exist? These are all questions that Australian science journalist Wendy Zukerman aims to answer in her first season of 'Science Vs.' Courtesy Wendy Zukerman Unimpressed with your downloaded podcasts? Try listening to the 'GymCastic' podcast, which has a particularly great interview with former gymnast and human meme McKayla Maroney. Julie Jacobson, AP Tara Lipinski and Johnny Weir had a podcast out just in time for the Rio Games, called 'Tara and Johnny,' and it's a winner. Courtesy NBC Sports Fullscreen The show 'Reply All' bills itself as "a show about the internet," but the web is really just a jumping-off point for fascinating stories about everything from how pizza rat can be seen as performance art, to One Direction conspiracy theories, and, recently, to the four-part series called 'On the Inside.' Courtesy Gimlet Media Best-selling author Malcolm Gladwell has an engaging new audio show, 'Revisionist History.' Anne Bailey Mike Rowe, best known for hosting 'Dirty Jobs,' has a pithy audio show, 'The Way I Heard It,' which is perfect for podcast listeners that lack the attention spans for hour-long stories.
